snippet: A new study suggests that receiving an IUD right after a cesarean delivery can help reduce unintended pregnancies and risks like prematurity.
abstract: Study published in journal Obstetrics and Gynecology suggests that doctors should give women who desire contraception, like intrauterine device, at time they deliver baby; study found that practice is far more effective at preventing unintended pregnancies and reducing number of babies conceived within 18 months after previous birth than simply telling new mothers to return six weeks after birth for contraception.
lead_paragraph: A new study suggests that receiving an IUD right after a cesarean delivery can help reduce unintended pregnancies and risks like prematurity.

headline.main: With New Study, New Mothers Seeking IUDs Are No Longer Urged to Wait
headline.print_headline: With New Study, New Mothers Seeking IUDs Are No Longer Urged to Wait
